description.narrative: Through capacity building and knowledge transfer, the cities of Lima and Piura will be able to improve parts of their Solid Waste Management (SWM) plan as a base for future decisions. The project execution will result in direct improvements to the environment, reduction of climate change emissions and will create temporary and long-term employment in both cities. Thisproject will enable Lima and Piura to involve the local private sector in the form of tenders and concession contracts in various Solid waste management aspects. The project focusses on the efficient use of existing facilities and improve the valorisation of solid waste throughout the chain, by extraction of valuable recyclables, improvement of the selection and recycling technologies, extraction of methane gas as energy source and by limiting necessary space for landfill activities and reuse the space of old landfills. The project includes technical, financial, political and juridical aspects needed to improve the overall waste management systems in both cities. Counterparts are the Municipalities of Lima and Piura, The Ministry of Environment, local NGO’s and organizations of informal recyclers, consultants and holders of large scale waste concessions.

Input for two new policies on key themes of Integrated Solid Waste Management:
1- Inclusion informal recyclers in transfer stations with focus on woman rights and independence, T - The local and Dutch experts revised existing programs managed by the Ministry of Environment of Peru (MINAM) and national egulations to provide recommendations for improvement and on how to improve the position of the Woman in the current situation as being reality in Peru. Practical pilots have to be suggested to be implemented directly in Lima.e project provides a set of recommendations for the inclusion of informal recyclers in transfer stations with focus on the independence of women. - Together with a local specialized NGO visits were made to organizations of informal recyclers and waste pickers. Their existing practices were analysed and compared to more efficient and more workers and women friendly options. Some of their initiatives are already good in line with common practices in other countries but on a very small scale. In presentations, discussions during site visits and in reports the proposed systems were explained. The options include small scale separation and transportation but also and preferably large scale recycling centres at the transfer stations or at the entrance of the landfills, where larger amounts and partially mechanical systems will help to raise th e profitability of the recycling and at the same time reduce the need for landfill space.

comment.narrative:
Two weeks of training was provided to the municipalities of Piura and Lima. Officers of the Solid Waste Management department were instructed in the theoretical basis of waste characterization in office presentations, workshops and discussion sessions, making use of local existing data and experience from the Netherlands.
actical training was carried out on two landfills in Lima, Zapallal and Portillo Grande and on the dumpsite of Piura, where the content of incoming waste trucks was analysed in detail.
The participating staff was than explained how to extrapolate these data and taught to elaborate best estimates for the waste content of a large area or city, needed fro the further design of the waste management system and landfill capacities.
